text: New paper in Proceedings B, an evolutionary model explaining age-dependent maternal allocation, led by Antoine and with collaborators Mike Bonsall (Oxford) and Andy Higginson (Exeter). This also got some news attention, and a radio interview in the Netherlands.
Hester is visiting Professor John Terblanche's laboratory at Stellenbosch University, South Africa, for 3 months.
We are delighted to welcome Molly Beastall back who joins the lab as a Royal Society funded research technician.
Sinead hosted Dr Njal Rollinson (University of Toronto) for a WEB seminar, 'Parental effects, extinction, and a resolution to the paradox of stasis'.
Mathilda gave a seminar 'Regulation of a tsetse-bacteria mutualism' at the Bristol Round Table Talks series.

New paper in Proceedings B! A review about insect-host control of obligate, intracellular symbiont density, led by Mathilda; with Antoine and our collaborators Dr Fleur Ponton (Macquarie) and Professor Mike Bonsall (Oxford) as co-authors.

Phd opportunities! Sinead is co-supervisor on the following SWBio DTP opportunity on maternal effects in honeybees (lead supervisor Christoph Grueter, Bristol *deadline 6 December*; and NERC GW4 DTP opportunity on life history evolution in humans (lead supervisor Eric Potsma, Exeter) *deadline 10 January*.

Congratulations to Lauren who has started a position as Research Assistant at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine working on mosquito rearing and behavioural experiments in the context of insecticide resistance, with Dr Priscille Barreaux. She will continue to work on her MRes part-time!

We say farewell to Antoine now that the BBSRC grant has ended. He is starting a position with Drs Ellen Brooks-Pollock, Hannah Christensen and Leon Danon and the wider 'Joint UNIversities Pandemic and Epidemiological Research' (JUNIPER) modelling consortium as a senior research associate (Bristol Vet School) to develop mechanistic and data-driven models of COVID-19.

New paper! Effects of maternal age and stress on offspring quality in a viviparous fly, in Ecology Letters. Led by Dr Jennifer Lord at LSTM and including several colleagues from our interdisciplinary BBSRC project. Featured on Bristol Research news page.
The mini-documentary about our BBSRC project on reproductive senescence in tsetse, Burrowing for Knowledge, featured at the Bristol Science Film Festival.
We welcome Bethany Groves on a BBSRC-funded Research Experience Placement. She'll be in the lab for 6 weeks measuring maternal behaviour in Diploptera punctata.
Sinead was invited to give a talk at the VectorBiTE annual symposium.
Hester co-organised a symposium GW4 Climate, for early-career researchers in GW4 institutions (Bath, Bristol, Cardiff, Exeter) on climate change solutions and how to communicate them.

Antoine gave a presentation at the Evolution conference (joint annual meeting of the American Society of Naturalists, the Society for the Study of Evolution, and the Society of Systematic Biologists) on 'An age-dependent framework of optimal maternal allocation regarding energy intake and metabolic costs, and the impact of nutritional stress in a viviparous disease vector'.
Sinead gave a seminar at the University of Veterinary Medicine Vienna (hosted by Dr Stefan Fischer).
Sinead gave a seminar at the Groningen Institute for Evolutionary Life Sciences, University of Groningen (hosted by Dr Hannah Dugdale and Dr Alexandra Sparks).

Mathilda has taken over from Antoine the organisation of the Theory Discussion Group, which brings researchers from Bristol and Exeter (and sometimes further afield) to discuss and develop new theoretical models in behaviour, ecology, and evolution.

Leavers and incomers: we welcome Sara Brabant who is joining EVE lab for a 4-month internship during her Master's, and say goodbye to Dr Kwasi Asante who finished his BCAI project in Bristol but will continue to analyse and write-up the data as he pursues other research opportunities in Ghana.

Sinead hosted Dr Kavita Isvaran from the Indian Institute of Science Bangalore giving a research seminar 'Investigating trait evolution in the wild: How multiple selection pressures shape animal behaviour and life history'.

Molly successfully defended her MRes thesis 'Maternal and Social Effects During Early Life on the Development and Life History Traits of the Pacific Beetle Cockroach'. Thanks to Dr James Gilbert (external) and Professor Richard Wall (internal) for being examiners and helpful input. Minor corrections have since been accepted so Molly has formally been awarded her degree!
Hester joins the Government Office for Science (SAGE Secretariat) for 3 months as part of the BBSRC Professional Internships for PhD students (PIPS) scheme.

FUNDED MRES OPPORTUNITY! We are excited to announce an opportunity to apply for a fully-funded (for UK students) Master's by Research studentship, on transgenerational effects in crop pests. Deadline 7 January. See our advert and others here.
Sinead is giving a seminar at the Centre for Research in Animal Behaviour, University of Exeter.

Three new papers! Sinead and Antoine have written a review on 'The evolution of sensitive periods in development: insights from insects', for a special issue in Current Opinion in Behavioral Sciences, and Sinead was part of a collaboration led by Professor Barbara Taborsky which resulted in an opinion paper, 'Towards an Evolutionary Theory of Stress Responses' published in Trends in Ecology & Evolution. Finally, with Lee Haines and others on our BBSRC Reproductive Senescence team, we've published a paper in BioEssays about tsetse giving birth to relatively enormous live young, entitled 'Big Baby, Little Mother: Tsetse Flies Are Exceptions to the Juvenile Small Size Principle'.

We welcome Mathilda Whittle, funded by the EPSRC and a Bristol-Macquarie cotutelle studentship, for a PhD on maternal effects and host-microbiome-pathogen interactions, co-supervised by Dr Fleur Ponton (Macquarie) and working also with Professor Mike Bonsall (Oxford).
Antoine hosted Dr Shannon Ladeau (Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies) for a seminar entitled 'Understanding the heterogenous 'riskscape' of mosquito-borne disease risk in temperate cities'.

We welcome Kwasi Asante, funded by the Bristol Centre for Agricultural Innovation, for a six-month project with Professor Richard Wall to identify the optimal application of neem to control cowpea weevils, while minimising impact on their parasitoid natural enemies.

PHD OPPORTUNITY: A fully funded PhD studentship is available to work with Sinead, Antoine and our collaborators Dr Fleur Ponton (Macquarie) and Professor Mike Bonsall (Oxford) on host-microbiome-pathogen interactions. Full details of the project are here. Please get in touch if you are interested or have any questions, and apply by 15 July!

New paper! Associations between prenatal anxiety, breastfeeding and child growth and puberty: data from the ALSPAC study. Sinead collaborated with colleagues at the Bristol Medical School (Doretta Caramaschi and Gemma Ford) and two super MSci students on the Reproduction and Development MSc programme, India Wright and Vee Ashburn, and this is part of a special issue on Cohort Methods and Applications in Human Biology.

New paper! Vimbai Tarusikirwa et al. on thermal plasticity in the invasive south American tomato pinworm. This was funded by a UoB GCRF Parternship Building award (2018) between Sinead and Casper Nyamukondiwa at the Botswana International University of Science and Technology.

We joined labs across the world in having to rapidly shut down due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including the difficult task of shutting down a long-term experiment. We are working from our homes, scattered across the UK, but come together for virtual coffee breaks and meetings.

Funding! We were delighted to be awarded funds from the Royal Society Public Engagment Award to develop a boardgame (aimed at primary-school children) on parasites and the arthropods that transmit them.
Sinead gave a seminar at the Centre for Academic Mental Health in Bristol.
We enjoyed hosting Laura Ross from Edinburgh University for the Monday Research Seminar.

New paper! Shatha Alqurashi (PhD co-supervised by Sinead, main supervisor Richard Wall) published the first paper from her PhD on the nutritional requirements for survival and reproduction in the blowfly, Lucilia sericata
Antoine and Sinead hosted Lauren Cator (Imperial College) for a seminar visit in Bristol
Sinead gave a plenary at the ASAB Winter Meeting

Sinead and Antoine awarded an International Strategic Fund award from University of Bristol for a project entitled 'The interactive effect of maternal nutrition and microbiome on offspring immunity and fitness', with Dr Fleur Ponton (Macquarie University) - total £2,730.
Sinead gave a seminar at the University of Lausanne (hosted by Ornela de Gasperin)
Welcome to new lab members, Hester Weaving (BBSRC SWBio PhD), Molly Beastall (MRes) and Lauren Marchant (MRes)!

Sinead spends a few days with the Developmental Evolutionary Ecological Psychology lab and gives a seminar at the Behavioural Science Institute on 'The long arm of early-life effects' (Radboud University, Nijmegen)

Sinead presents work on stress and breastfeeding at the Society for the Study of Human Biology annual meeting (Oxford Brookes) and the Mechanisms and Evolution of Intergenerational Change conference (Wellcome Genome Campus, Cambridge)

New paper! Antoine has published results from his previous postdoc on malaria control (Penn State University, USA), involving months of release recaptures with fantastic volunteers in Ivory Coast to explore the cumulative effects of a 'Lethal House Lure' on malaria mosquitoes mortality
Antoine gives talk on modelling tsetse-borne disease at the IDDConf in Cumbria, UK
New paper! Sinead and Mike Bonsall (MERG, Oxford) have published a study in Ecology & Evolution, linking cellular dynamics with life history outcomes
John Hargrove visits Bristol to discuss the BBSRC project and related tsetse work
Gabby di Pol (BBSRC-STARS summer student) has joined EVE lab for 2 months working on trypanosome coinfections, with Lori Peacock and Wendy Gibson
Sinead gives a research seminar at the University of Aberdeen (hosted by Julien Martin)
Sinead visits Marshall McCue at Sable Systems International (Las Vegas, USA) to discuss measuring isotopes in tsetse breath
Antoine attends the African sleeping sickness meeting in Warwick organised by our collaborator Kat Rock (HAT MEPP project)
Antoine and Sinead attend the annual BBSRC Reproductive Senescence project meeting at LSTM in Liverpool
